reviewText:
Forced showdown is a twinstick shooter rogue-like card game. Thats obviously a lot of descriptors, so the worry would be does it handle those things well. I would say yes, but it does have its problems. The core gameplay is very fun, at least with the 'main' character and the bow and arrow guy. The other two characters, in my opinion, aren't as fun to play with. They are, at least early on, difficult to play as because the game rewards a conservative playstyle and the two melee characters aren't really conservative at all.

So, the game is like an arena TV show. Your working towards the final boss and you have cameras following you around during every arena. You fight enemies, then you reach a boss. Two bosses, you fight a boss that opens a door. Do that a few times and you beat a show. Sounds like a lot, and it is. You'll probably die. Winning a run isn't easy. You have to be good/lucky, and just hope you survive and get the right cards.

Cards. So, you have a pre built deck and you can also build a deck out of cards you earn by earning gold, and spinning for them. The card building has a super Hearthstone vibe, but there are very few cards that reach that level of complexity, most cards are very very simple. +80 health, +45% damage. There are more interesting cards but these passive upgrades are what I usually build my deck around, because its a guarenteed upgrade unlike spells and consumables which usually have some condition.

This game, at least in the beta build I played, has some issues. It runs kinda like crap, it lags frequently at the end of battles and I had it crash on me once. Luckily, it doesn't often lag during a big fight, although it can happen. I hope there is a day one patch that fixes this, and if there is I will update. I also have an issue, but its probably just preference, where the games kinda last a long time. It can take 90 minutes to get to the end of a run, and then you just lose. Luckily there are quests and you get gold for cards so its not like you just got nothing, but doing a 90 minute run and losing can be upsetting. I would have preferred if a run was a bit shorter and not as drawn out.

I discovered this game on twitch, and because of twitch the game will launch with a 12% discount(I'll get a higher one for getting a beta key). I would definitely recommend it at its base price if the idea of a twin-stick roguelite card game appeals to you. It definitely appeals to me. The game handles deck building, twin-stick shooting and its rogue-like elements very well.

Buy At Full Price

reviewText:
FORCED SHOWDOWN is an action indie RPG game, a successor to FORCED: Slightly Better Edition, a well-known co-op RPG game.
If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.

What is happening in the game:You are in some kind of a game show, where you are FORCED (see what I did there?) to fight enemies that are placed across the level. They get tougher after each stage, but you do as well.

Pros:    Graphics | The game truly looks amazing! Levels look great, they have a lot of little details that fill the screen and make everything look good. I'm talking about torches, flowers, barrels and so on. Variety is also a big advantage, as levels look different from one another. If you're interested about graphic settings, there is plenty of them.
Amount of Gameplay | There is a lot of gameplay included in this game. You have different campaigns, but you also have many quests to complete. Since campaigns are very full of content, there is also a great replayability value in this game.
Cards | This is (to some degree) also a card game. Let me explain this. You get a card every level and you can choose whether you want to use it or not. Every level, you also get some mana, which you need for activating the chosen card. If you want to activate a card that is really good, you will probably have to wait a few levels to save up enough mana to be able to use that card. I think that cards are a nice addition to the gameplay and it's great that's the game's focus is not completely on the cards, but just uses them as powerups and bonuses. If you want, you can also build your own decks. And if you don't want certain cards at the beginning, you can choose to change some of them to different ones (you don't know which new ones you will get, though).
Weapons and Abilities | You can have different weapons and also different abilities, depending on what character you choose. Abilities do help a lot, unless you forget to use them like me :P Weapons are kind of cool, since they behave a bit differently than they do in other games. For example, continuously firing a laser gun for a few seconds will result in a huge blast at the end of that period, which will deal a great amount of damage. This also makes sure that you time your shots right and aim at the strongest enemy just when the blast is about to occur.
Cutscenes and Voice Acting | The cutscenes are well-made and are also voice acted by an announcer♥♥♥♥♥♥ee called C-SAR. He acts with a really exciting voice and together with sound effects and music, he really makes cutscenes great.
Menu Appearance | I know that this is not affecting the gameplay, but a game also needs to take care of how it appears when a person first launches it. The mix of purple colours and just the right lightning definitely leaves a great first impression. The menu is also intuitive and easy to navigate.
Achievements | There are more than 60 achievements in this game, which is great for some people who like to be complimented by the game for their marvelous actions and advanced skills. The achievements are also equally divided between different difficulties. By that I mean that some games have all achievements fairly hard to achieve or the exact opposite, but Showdown is not one of those games.
Controller Support | I don't play with my controller very often, but this seemed like a good game to try playing it with my Steam Controller. I tried it and, to my surprise, the game played better than with a keyboard. I like the control layouts
Regular Updates | Updates are coming very often, approximately one every week. And they're not just some small updates! They all have tons of added content, tweaks, fixes, balanced enemies and weapons, performance improvements and more. The gaming community certainly needs more active developers like this one.
Cons:    Performance Issues | Even though there were many fixes and the situation definitely did get better, I still experience some frame drops and lags. My computer also struggles a bit when I launch the game. But, as I said, the situation keeps getting better with almost every update, so I'm looking forward to seeing this game issue-free in near future.
Loading Times | Not a big issue, since there are not many loading screens, but the ones that are present take a long time to do their job.
Enemy Variety | Sometimes I feel like there are not enough different enemies. You rarely have to take different approaches in order to beat them. You don't have to adapt too much, they just get a bit stronger and maybe a bit more aggressive.
Lack of Minimap | In certain arenas, you could use a minimap to see the stage layout and maybe even enemy positions. This is not a major problem, though.
Trading Cards | Sadly, they are not present. The developers have this one their list of planned stuff, but apparently, they're more busy with other things.
Windows Only | There is no Linux and Mac support right now, but this is supposedly planned as well. We'll see how that goes.
The final verdict:Overall, this game is really good. There are a lot of good things and some bad things, but there is really no doubt about this game's quality. In case you haven't read the whole thing: the quality is high above average. I really like how this game looks and how it plays. I'm not the biggest fan of card games, but Showdown has them integrated in an unusual way that is, in my opinion, much better than in most games.
There are some issues in terms of performance and a lack of some features, but the updates are so frequent that I don't have any fear that everything is going to be fixed sooner or later.
If you like RPGs and if you liked the original Forced, definitely give this game a try. It's worth it.

Greetings,
BirdCute

Note that my copy of this game was obtained for free for reviewing purposes. However, this did not affect the quality and objectivity of this review.

PROS:Satisfying twin-stick gameplay that improves upon the mechanics from the original FORCED.
Hearthstone-style card system creates a whole new hybrid style balancing deck building skill and RNG effectively.
Great looking aesthetic and amazing art direction accentuates the “game show” feel.
Daily events give the game more replayability by allowing you to compete on leaderboards in monthly tournaments.
CONS:  Game has some problems with low replayability if you do not enjoy the daily events as there are only 3 campaigns.
A bit buggy at times, ESPECIALLY if you play Ravager there are some strange interactions with his dash.
Only 4 characters feels a bit lacking.
NO multiplayer, which is odd considering one of the selling points of the original FORCED was the co-op.
SUMMARY:FORCED SHOWDOWN is a twin-stick shooter that introduces a unique card system into the traditional formula. Instead of relying on traditional itemization your upgrades are based on the cards that you put in your deck. What this does is allow you to customize how you want to play your champion while still keeping some of the random nature of a rogue-lite style game. While I don’t think the card system is going to be redefining any genres, it works well and the game represents one of the most polished twin stick shooters in recent times. The solid gameplay and well developed aesthetic gives the game a feeling of quality, much more so than the original FORCED. The game is good, very good but it’s also a game that I believe needs additional content in the future to keep players around. So far following this game I’ve come to trust the developers are planning on supporting this game to a great degree, and hopefully more campaigns and characters help flesh out an already great addition to the twin-stick genre.

Honestly, I wasn't expecting to get hooked on this game from the get go.

It reminds me in some way of Hand of Fate, another brilliant rogue-lite with cards and lots of fighting, but less mean to the player. HoF could really mess you up with one or two bad draws, while FS allows you to overcome even the toughest challenges by your own skills. Mind you, this game gets difficult very fast, as even the first major boss can really kick your behind if you don't pack some good cards. You'll die a lot, but that is expected with games like this one.

As for the deckbuilding part, it borrows some bits from Hearthstone. Your deck can contain 30 cards, up to 2 copies of each are allowed and mana curve goes up to 8 because that's how many arenas are in each ''dungeon''. The cards and heroes allow for varied play styles, so you can go full tank or DPS, or even play the rare cards that grant bonuses when your HP is low if you're in mood for risk with high rewards. The gameplay is very solid and you can really feel the weight of the punches and big spells, especially when lots of explosions happen and the screen ''thumps''.

All in all, a great game, that only lacks some sort of multiplayer and more character variety to become amazing. I see myself playing this for months to come. Well done, BetaDwarf!

FORCED SHOWDOWN is the second game out of the BetaDwarf studio and is the second installment in their arena-brawler genre. In broad strokes the game is built on the mechanics

introduced in their first game, but adds a ton of replayability and overall gameplay as the genre  shifts to a single-player focussed game.

The gameplay is fast and exciting with tons of customizability you know from creating your own card decks in magic or hearthstone.
You get rewarded for completing arenas even though you don't complete the full run, giving you the feel that you are always progressing and creating better decks for the challenges at hand.


The artistic theme does not shy away from making a couple of jokes; like Ratbo, a minigun-wielding rat, or a pirate rat in a rocket spaceship. Which at first can appear out of sync, however reveals itself as an approach to keep the focus on the gameplay.

I thouroughly enjoyed this game and it addresses some of the elements that was lacking in their first installment. (Replayability and customizability)
I will definitely kick in more time in this game.

The relatable title is obviously FORCED, but if you are looking into game-mechanics you should also look to a combination of Hearthstone, Magicka, Diablo and the roguelike element.


Features:

- Fast-paced non-stop combat
- Deep customizability and strategic approach to fight within the arenas
- Card-game-like pre-game customization
- 'Perma death' or 'Progression reset' - Roguelike element

- Oh and treasure goblins. Sweet, sweet, treasure goblins.

You select a campaign to play

reviewText:
This key was obtained from the developer for the purposes of review.

Target Audience:    Action RPG fans who want bang for their buck, and want a little bit of a show to go with it.

Video Review:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qgMuwnTv8nk

Summary:
Games have been using Twitch well to promote themselves before launch, and Forced Showdown did well in tying the launch discount with Twitch minutes watched. But don't let that gimmick make you overlook a game that's solid in the Action RPG genre. It's roguelite elements in the card deck building genre are pretty good: as there's good card variety here and a nice selection of heroes. Combat does strong at first, in particular in the challenge area, and yet the game is still fair. Now over time, the variety does start to get hurt if you don't keep unlocking new content, which can be a challenge with some of the stuff that the game throws at you at times. But that takes a lot longer then other games in this specific combination of genre elements, and I was still having fun at 10+ hours with no problems. The game delivers in a bang from buck perspective, even without the discount. Just be ready to deal with some performance issues (especially on the end of waves), that never hit game breaking, but are very annoying.

Lists:
Positives:
Good Series of Heroes with different play styles that hit a good spectrum of typical Action RPG basics (melee, ranged, etc.)
Good set of cards that don't hit just the typical stat boosts, but have significant boosts to abilities and some interesting side effects.
Enemies present aren't cookie cutter, like the buggy that swing around a laser over and over again, or an enemy specifically designed for you to not kill.
Difficulty is good with its roguelite elements. You have to pay attention to what the opponent is playing, or you'll find yourself dead as you charged in recklessly to take a ton of damage.
Like the Twitch formula and taking the game show/spectacle format to a meta level.
Controls are where they need to be for a game like this. In particular with mouse/keyboard and the archer, which gives the precision you need to fire around corners.
The puns are strong with this game. And as a pun lover, I have absolutely no problem with that.
In game models do have some significant detail on them.
Negatives:
Performance can be an issue, in particular with ending the round and the loading associated with it. Frame drops now and again.
Lacks any sort of strong narrative or story. While the presentation elements do work in terms of a game show, you have no real idea who these characters are. If this is important to you, this game may not be for you.
Explosions/Lasers lack an oompf. This was tested by turning off the sounds and seeing their impact/hearing the lack of impact. Seems to me that it's mostly visual, and they really didn't feel different otherwise.
Over time, the game loses Variety. Usually this is high on my negatives list, but Forced Showdown does a reasonable job of keeping that from happening soon, as after 10+ hours, you were unlocking new content and finding new stuff still. It's just as a rate smaller then I would like for a game like this.
Very Minor: The game does at times lose a bit of its spectacle thanks to its isometric view. This is sorta unavoidable due to the genre.

reviewText: Like many working their way through the public school system, I had a years long fling with Magic: The Gathering. Besides piles of cardboard still littered around my apartment, what I took away from my time with Magic was an appreciation for all the little moving parts of a game, whether that game is physical or digital. The interactions between mechanics, the thousands of permutations possible between two decks, the arcane rules that cause both excitement and frustration—it’s all fascinating to me. FORCED SHOWDOWN has a bit of that same magic, turning the power ups and items that fuel a roguelite’s procedural systems into cards you can place into a deck. It’s not perfect, but it is a neat twist on the genre that kept me engaged throughout my time with the game.\n\nWant to know more? Read my full review of the game over  at TechRaptor	[techraptor.net]

I'm re-writing my review for this game, after giving it another shot. My first impression of this game was really bad, though I had a pretty bad set of arenas and I didnt like the starting character. CGamer commented on my review as seen here: http://i.imgur.com/AxIAbgy.png Massive props to him for going out of his way to get me another coupon (though refunding it did actually return it to me but its that he went out of his way to actually do it that counts). After reinstalling and conceding the first game to unlock a second character, the game became A LOT more enjoyable.

So first off let me explain why I didnt like the game the first time:
The squire of light is the character you start with. He's pretty basic and really easy to play. I'd first bought the game thinking it was multiplayer (Which was bad on my part) so I then started treating it as a single player game and wanted to see if I'd like it before the 2 hour refund time. The Squire of light was just boring to play to me. The game was so that I didnt know if I'd be challenged at all, I barely got hit after I'd played the first 2 arenas, everything died incredibly fast and the characters playstyle just didnt apeal to me. On top of all of that, I randomly selected the same 2 templates multiple times and didnt have any fun fights in them anyways.

The second time I played:
I played Volcar (I think is his name, the hammer guy). He's melee, he's got a melee attack that you can chargre rather than just aiming a laser at people, his starting deck is really fun, and most importantly his playstyle was alot more what I was looking for. I never played him in the original FORCED because my friends would pick him, so I intially went in thinking I'd try to make myself really tanky, because that's what I enjoy normally. But I quickly found that stacking as much offense and playing like a berserker was what I really enjoyed about him. Not only that but I got different tile sets this time and actually had some close counters in combat that made me really enjoy it alot more. As well as encountering new, harder enemies on tile sets I'd seen before.

Aside from my personal experiences of the game, I've always thought that the whole concept of the game is awesome. I love roguelikes, and if you do too, you'll most likely like this game as well. There's heavy replayability in the way you can build your character between each game. You've got your deck which you can customize, you get delt different cards each individual arena fight. Across a single campaign you'll basically 'level up' and get a set of boons to pick from that can give you different buffs. So as per your typical roguelike, you can be delt a very bad hand that can make your run very hard. Luckily in this game you can most likely just outskill everything despite being weak from what cards/boons you're offered. Which is something I love. Challenge and replayability is important in roguelikes.

Anyways, I just wanted to update my review so this game has the rating it deserves. I'll probably update it as updates for the game come out and as I get further in the game.

reviewText:
Video Version:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e0uAI-cusAg

What is Forced Showdown?  It’s a Galactic Gameshow where you’re the contestant competing in gladiator battles to become a crowd favorite.  But that’s not where the game ends.  They also found a way to cram Hearthstone into it.  It’s actually hilariously obvious how the devs are huge Blizzard fans, because the game even has Treasure Goblins, sort of.  Don’t take that for a criticism though.  They have done so in a creative way.

So where does the Hearthstone mention come in to play?  Well, each arena run is based on a deck of cards.  The match starts with a 4 card draw from a 30 card deck.  You can keep the cards or mulligan them.  You also have a mana bar which increases by one for each subsequent arena match in a particular gladiator battle you win.  The cards are comprised of upgrade cards which increase damage or other abilities directly, spells which have unique instant effects such as gaining mana temporarily or drawing a new card that costs less, and last consumables which give you for the most part single arena active skills temporarily like throwing a powerful bomb.

The gameplay is very satisfying with great effects, solid visceral abilities and nice quick action.  Where the game really shines though is in the audio.  I mean this in the nicest way possible.  This is an indie game and is the second title from Beta Dwarf.  It’s got no business having audio this good.  The voice acting is absolutely top notch with an amazing announcer introducing the lead up into the matches, great boss voices and an incredible blood pumping action heavy sound track.

As with any game there are some elements that aren’t so great.  To start with, there is a limited selection of 4 heroes and 3 companions.  This is the kind of game that doesn’t rely on the levels to be the unique element and as a result, I’d liked to have seen more player characters.  The cards do have some character specific variants, so I can see how that would complicate things, but I think it’s worth the effort.

I’m not a huge fan of some of the UI choices.  The card wheel where you spend your gold on new cards feels janky and cheap compared to the rest of the experience.  The UI for building decks has a fair bit of visual overlap on what is clickable while filtering cards and I found it a bit awkward to use.  And the UI for showing quests also feels pretty bare bones.  For a game that is as flashy as this, these UI elements are boring.

It also has some very long load times in between matches which is not good.  They’re having some server issues too which essentially causes the daily and season structure to be non-functional.  As I understand it, this is a pretty high priority for them to fix right now, but it’s still a little broken.  I’ve also confirmed with the developer that the build I’m playing on is the release version.

My conclusion is simple.  Forced Showdown is a game that surprised me.  I went into the game expecting a crappy little brawler and what I got was anything but that.  Combat is responsive and fun.  The audio is hilarious and incredible both in music and voice-over.  The game looks great and plays great.  Yes some of the menu UI is boring and it’s got reasonably long load times but for $20, I think this game is great value and absolutely worth playing.

The game is a mix of Deck Building and arena combat, and if you think that'd get repetitive... you're in for a big surprise!

Video Review:
Watch the video for the most complete impression of the game and its advantages, gameplay, possible problems and technical prowess.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qqu2g9sTCzk&ab_channel=GuyLogic

Textual summary:
As always, a short textual summary won’t do the game justice compared to a 30 minute video so take this as the summary it is!

The game combines arena combat, deck building, card collecting and score attacks in a comedic and interesting mix of elements that fight the inherent repetitive nature of a game like this.

First… there are quite a few cards available, and more to unlock and with various characters (4) available for play as well as different playstyles you will have many opportunities to fiddle, tinker and make up decks for each of them to try out. And daily challenges in the seasons result in you often having to tinker with your decks for the best possible result.

The game has no micro transactions or anything of the kind, and while I don’t know if the developers have any plans for this, currently once you buy the game you will be able to unlock everything without any Pay-2-win nonsense.

The arena combat is fast, intense, and colorful and the modifiers in each engagement keep it fresh time and again even when you are, in essence facing about a dozen enemy types in total. Those modifiers range from stronger enemies, benefits to you, and influence how a arena run pans out, meaning not just your deck needs a solid strategy but each arena requires you to think and plan ahead.

A concern I had was RNG, and outside of some issues with explanations, most of that can be mitigated with experience in the game. RNG really isn’t a major concern.

Overall technically the game runs great and has an acceptable options menu – do note, if you are colorblind, you can experience issues as the game uses classical color schemes of red, green and blue to indicate quite a few action elements. Some minor issues, I hope will be fixed ASAP in relation to bugs and crashes.

Overall, I like this game a TON and the fact that I’ve yet to beat it and the various options and abilities I have yet to unlock give a lot of value for money. I wholeheartedly recommend this title.

reviewText:
I'm ~30 hours in, and I'm really enjoying this so far.  The combat is a fun, fast-paced, Diablo-style slaughterfest, and the addition of strategic elements really makes the game much more enjoyable and gives a sense of progression in a very fun and unique way.  The difficulty is certainly high, especially once you complete the first show, but a little determination, a little luck, and a few new cards can be all you need to turn it around.  It's a big pile of fun that I've had difficulty pulling myself away from.

There are warts, however:  I've run into some crashing issues, and situations where the game will simply hang the entire machine for a few seconds, but these seem to be getting better with each patch, and BetaDwarf is pushing patches very quickly so far.  The only other issue I have isn't with the game itself, but rather with dicumentation:  It's almost impossible to find good information about the game online.  There is a wikia page, but it has outdated versions of cards, lots of incorrect information, and a new ad on every page (at least on mobile).  Some of it is that the game is so new it hasn't yet built up a community, but BetaDwarf has not done a good job up to now of seeding this information to the players & potential community-builders.  Hopefully, this is just another symptom of small team with a brand-new product; They're probably working like mad right now, and these kinds of niceties will come later.

Maybe once they're done with that, they might work on a multi-player component, or Linux/OS X/SteamOS compatibility??  Pretty please??

Despite these things, I still couldn't not recommend this game.  It's just that much fun.

I wouldn't say this is a horrible game but I cannot recommend it unless you're someone who really really likes deck building games. I had some fun with this even if it ended up not really being my thing.

The stages are simple and tiny, but for the type of game where you're running through a dozen arenas with each arena having ten fights it makes sense for them to be so small; I just wish they weren't so repetitive. The random arena affects try to help with that but most of the time you never want to choose any of the positive ones since it increases enemy numbers, which is usually worse than the negative effects you could instead pick up to lower enemy numbers.
